utterances: How could the benefit outweigh the substantial risk?
Wyeth could have gone back to the FDA at any time to change the label, and it didn't.
In the absence of new information, we could not change the label.
Supporting Wyeth in the Supreme Court today was the Bush administration, which in a sharp break with decades of FDA policy is now siding with the pharmaceutical industry.
Justice Ginsburg asked why the administration had changed positions, but got no answer from Deputy Solicitor General Edwin Kneedler.
There are 11,000 drugs on the market.
Is the FDA really monitoring all of them to see if there is new information that should be noted on a label?
Why isn't the fact that a certain number of people are getting gangrene - why isn't that new information that justifies the manufacturer strengthening the warnings on the label?
If you read the regulation, it says the manufacturer can do that.
End of case.
The risk of gangrene is not new information.
Diana Levine's lawyer, David Frederick, rebutted that answer when he stood to argue.
In the years since the label was approved by the FDA, he said there have been more than 20 amputations in cases involving the IV push method.
Wyeth knew about these, but did not connect the dots, he said, to warn that the IV push method should not be used.
Justice Antonin Scalia and Chief Justice Roberts, voices raised, went after him with a vengeance.
Excuse me, those risks were set forth on the labeling approved by the FDA.
The FDA never considered the relative risks of the IV push method and other methods of administering the drug.
People can say it's safe for you to walk down the sidewalk.
That doesn't mean there is no risk that you get hit by lightning or something else.
If you're telling me the FDA acted irresponsibly, then sue the FDA.
(Singing) Well, that's your own opinion and you're entitled to it.
I'll be lost in oblivion if we don't continue through it.
I was going to say by the words, my bow technique does put you at a disadvantage, as the mandolin player.
Where's my pick doesn't quite do it.
In fact, at one point we did a salute at the end of a take that they were filming.
And they had actually sort of crossed bows - Three Musketeers style - and I guess may be my role is like D'Artagnan or something.
And so, I tried to get the pick and it actually fell out of my fingers and it was so - it was a traumatic experience for me.
The mandolin pick fell out of your hand.
The mandolin pick fell to the ground.
Humiliating.
It was shameful.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
This is a shameful way of getting sound out of a string.
Look at how - it's so small and insignificant in comparison.
And so precise.
I'm glad you said that.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
I think we're verging on some mandolin jokes here, if we're not careful.
Right.
Could be trouble.
Goat Rodeo,"" what exactly is the goat rodeo?
Chris Thile?
It means it's an aviation term, I guess, where so many loose ends, so many things that could go wrong that you need to go right for everything to turn out not utterly disastrous.
And we kind of felt a kinship with that concept.
And did it spring up organically, Yo-Yo, from the sessions or what?
I think so because so many of the songs, their working titles, had rodeo attached to it.
So, we had ""Irish Rodeo."" We had all kinds of rodeos.
And then there was a ""Goat Rodeo,"" and Chris looked it up one day and we thought, gee, that's a version of us.
It's kind of everybody could be a leader or everybody could be a follower at various times.
And I think the vast amounts of fun that we have, which is, for me, that's the goat rodeo part.
How can we ever get any work done...
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
...when we're laughing all of the time?
And that's actually the part that we love the most.
It's a great balance between the two.
Well, would you play another tune for us?
What would you like to do?
Atta Boy.
That'll work.
One, two, one, two, three...
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC, ""ATTA BOY"")
I'm talking with Chris Thile, Edgar Meyers, Stuart Duncan and Yo-Yo Ma.
And that's the song ""Atta Boy"" from ""The Goat Rodeo Sessions."" Tell me some stories from your recording sessions.
I'm trying to figure out who was playing, not which part on an instrument, but which parts are in the room.
When you've been trying to conduct an interview about a fairly serious subject, have you ever had somebody take a bow and stick it in your ear?
I've never have, Edgar Meyer.
If it happened today, I'm thinking.
You haven't.
Right.
Well, see, if it sounds appealing maybe you should join our band.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
Because that sort of thing happens quite regularly.
Yes.
And what's...
We write new lyrics to the instrumental songs.
That's true.
And some you will never ever hear.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
